body:
>  JUnit 5 does not distinguish between failure and error

That's correct. The JUnit Platform does not distinguish between different types of `Throwable` with regard to the _exception_ associated with a _failed_ `TestIdentifier`.

See `org.junit.platform.engine.TestExecutionResult.failed(Throwable)` for details.

> Instead, the Maven output says there are 2 failures.

That's correct.

> Similaryly, there are 2 tests declared as failure and besides, the output says there that 2 containers found, but if I'm not wrong there should be just one, since there is only one test class in the project.
> 
> Is this a bug or I am misinterpreting something here?

You're misinterpreting something here. ðŸ˜‰ 

The 1st _container_ is the `JupiterTestEngine`; the 2nd _container_ is the `PlayingWithReportingTest` test class. Thus, there are in fact 2 containers.
Closing this issue as _works as designed_.

> Keep up with great work!

Thanks! ðŸ˜Ž

rename.from: JUnit 5 does not distinguish between failure and error
rename.to: JUnit Platform Surefire Provider does not distinguish between failure and error

body:
I'm reopening this issue because while neither JUnit Platform, JUnit Jupiter, nor JUnit 4 distinguish between failures and errors, Maven Surefire does (e.g. to support JUnit 3).

So, our Surefire provider should take the same approach as the one Surefire provides for JUnit 4:
https://github.com/apache/maven-surefire/blob/b54e33e68e9c3e13f8fca4b66dbb5c89a0a30715/surefire-providers/common-junit4/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/surefire/common/junit4/JUnit4RunListener.java#L112-L119

issue.title: assertAll()'s exception-handling behavior turns all test programming errors into test failures

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Problem

JUnit's `assertAll()` is widely recommended (e.g. [Baeldung - assertAll() vs Multiple Assertions in JUnit5](https://www.baeldung.com/junit5-assertall-vs-multiple-assertions) and on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40796756/assertall-vs-multiple-assertions-in-junit5)) as a way to group assertions and report all failures at once instead of stopping at the first failure. However, its documented behavior is to _assert that all supplied executables do not throw exceptions._ This is fine for actual test failures, but any **error** (e.g. `NullPointerException`, `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`) is now turned into a test **failure**. This obscures the actual problem; the developer has to look into the `MultipleFailuresError`, realize that the thrown exception is not an `AssertionError` to be able to fix the test programming error (maybe those assertions depend on each other and should be moved out of the `assertAll()`, maybe a null check was forgotten, etc.)

## Suggested solution

I think that `assertAll()` should distinguish between test assertion failures and all other exceptions, and only throw `MultipleFailuresError` if there are test assertion failures, but instead throw a new `MultipleErrorsError` if there's at least one non-assertion exception (programming errors take precedence over test failures). The latter would be reported as a test error, not a test failure, and would contain the original exception(s) as a cause. With that, the behavior would be consistent with the sequential execution of multiple assertions, supporting what I perceive as the predominant use case of `assertAll()` (i.e. executing _all_ assertions and not stopping at the first).

## Alternative solutions

* If changing the behavior of `assertAll()` is not an option, a new method a la `assertEach()` could be added that behaves as described above. JavaDocs would have to clearly distinguish between the two methods and explain the difference in behavior. (However, the current behavior of `assertAll()` could be trivially kept by using `assertAll(() -> assertDoesNotThrow(...), ...);`.)
* A lightweight alternative would go without a new `MultipleErrorsError` and just throw the first non-assertion exception (similar to the existing special behavior for unrecoverable exceptions like OOM). Comprehensive failure reporting would only be for failures, not errors, and developers would have to run the test again to see if there are more errors, like in the case of sequential assertions. In fact, the Baeldung article mentioned above (which is based on JUnit 5.9.2) mistakenly assumed that `assertAll()` would behave like this:

> We should note that `assertAll()` only handles `AssertionError`. If any assertion were to end with an exception, rather than the usual `AssertionError`, execution stops immediately and the error output would relate to the exception, rather than `MultipleFailuresError`.
